awd_titl_txt: Radiation Transport in Strongly Coupled High-Energy-Density Plasmas
awd_abstract_narration:
Heath LeFevre is awarded an NSF Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at the University of Michigan – Ann Arbor. LeFevre will study High-Energy Density (HED) plasmas at the Omega and Omega EP laser facilities at the University of Rochester.  The project aims to understand and measure coupling between intense electromagnetic radiation and an HED plasma, a plasma with particularly high particle density and temperature.  The regime where effects of strong coupling on emission and absorption of radiation in HED plasmas is not well studied and is important to the physics of white dwarf stars and type Ia supernova, as well as for inertial confinement fusion plasmas.  Along with the research, LeFevre will conduct outreach, recruiting, and mentoring efforts aimed at increasing the diversity of students studying plasma physics. 

This study explores strongly coupled, radiation flux dominated plasmas, which are relevant to inertial confinement fusion, white dwarf stars, and type Ia supernova. This is a physics regime that is difficult to model and therefore the experimental results to be obtained at the University of Rochester’s high energy laser facilities are of fundamental interest to astrophysics and HED science research. Comparing results of these experiments with available radiation hydrodynamics, atomic kinetics, and radiation transport codes will quantify the effects of radiation coupling in these plasmas. This study will be able to eliminate common sources of uncertainty and error in HED physics models due to its use of multiple facilities and experimental conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This funding supported a single researcher as a postdoctoral research fellow. This is a position that a researcher will hold shortly after they finish their doctorate, and it is meant to provide an opportunity to develop their ideas and resume as they start a career. The science objective of this project was to explore the behavior of radiation in a nonideal plasma, a state of matter with free electrons and ions, where some of the standard assumptions no longer apply. These types of conditions are present in the cores of some stars and at the surface of neutron stars. It is possible to produce conditions like this in laboratories using lasers to implode small, plastic capsules. Additionally, this project set out to increase participation of students in plasma physics, and particularly from groups that have not participated in this type of work, historically. This was accomplished through mentorship of undergraduate students and through speaking to students about careers in plasma physics. This report will detail the efforts to study the behavior of radiation in dense plasmas and the broader impacts of this work, specifically as it relates to increasing participation in plasma physics.

This work explores the behavior of radiation, called radiation transport, in dense plasmas using laboratory experiments and computational models of the experiments. The analysis of the experiments uses comparisons of estimated measurements using the computational models to the experimental data.

The experiments use a set of 60 laser beams at the Laboratory for Laser Energetics at the University of Rochester, which is a national user facility, to irradiate the surface of a small, plastic capsule that is about 1 mm in diameter and hollow on the inside. The thickness of this shell of plastic is about 10 millionths of a meter thick. This plastic capsule has a layer of metal on the inside surface that is 0.2 millionths of a meter thick. When the 60 laser beams interact with the surface of the capsule, they deliver enough energy to create a plume of plasma. This creates an effect like a rocket that accelerates the rest of the capsule inwards in an implosion. When the imploding capsule reaches its smallest size, the resulting plasma reaches temperatures of over 100 million degrees and densities about 50 times the density of lead. This plasma emits x-rays that the experiments measure in a spectrum of different energies to learn about the conditions in the plasma. This x-ray data determines how the plasma behaves and provides information about the radiation transport. To test the effects of the dense plasma on radiation transport, these experiments used partial metal coatings on some of the capsules. This produced different features in the spectrum when looking at coated or uncoated portions of the capsules, indicating the role of radiation transport in these dense, nonideal plasmas.

The computational portion of the work modeled the capsule implosion. Then, a separate computational model, that was developed through this work, created an estimated spectrum to compare against the one measured in the experiments. This generally works well and generally captures the behavior of the experimental measurements. There are differences, which point to places where the models may not be capturing what is happening in the experiments correctly. This points to new directions of research to explore where models can be improved.

During this project, the supported researcher mentored undergraduate students who worked on research projects related to the behavior of radiation in dense plasmas. This trained them in tools used in the physics of plasmas and in the scientific method used in research work. Their contributions helped advance the understanding of the scientific work mentioned above.

A goal of this work was to reach out more broadly to talk about plasma physics. To do this, the supported researcher spoke at several summer schools for students from high school to college to describe plasma physics and the opportunities for a career in this field. Part of this included attending courses and programs to learn about the difficulties people from different backgrounds face and how to make sure everyone who pursues a career in science succeeds.

This work developed a tool to improve the training for new researchers using the facilities at the Laboratory for Laser Energetics. This will allow more people to have access to this facility and reduces the barrier to entry for scientists who are interested in pursuing work in this field.

In conclusion, this work investigated the radiation transport in dense plasmas where the typical assumptions about the plasma behavior do not apply. It did this through capsule implosion experiments using lasers and computational efforts to help understand the data. This project also conducted mentoring and outreach work to help people learn about plasma physics as a career.
